subject: Re: [junit] @BeforeClass throws NullPointerException

messageBody:
On 9/30/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> If you want to share data across instances, then it has to be
> class-level. That's Java. Hell, that's OO.

It's a philosophical difference.

Cedric believes that a test class is an instance by itself, which will
then have several test methods called on it in succession. This is the
way TestNG works, and it's the way that NUnit works as well. This
makes it easy to share common data between the test methods, as they
simply are the same instance. However, it exposes you to lack of test
isolation, which may mean that the tests are not order independent,
and also affect your abilty to run them concurrently.

Kent Beck obviously believes that each test _method_ is worthy of
being its own instance. This means that the tests _can_ be run in any
order, in parallel, etc, but means that they can not use instance data
to share state.

There is no right or wrong choice here - they represent solutions that
accept different balances of the competing forces. It is possible that
one or the other is more intuitive (certainly Cedric's argued that in
the past), but a counter-intuitive solution isn't necessarily _wrong_
just because it's counter-intuitive - that's what documentation is
for.
